item.title: CWNP
item.description:
CWNP

Welcome to the 802.11 series of blogs for beginners in the field of wireless networking. In this blog, we will discuss the basic components of the 802.11 MAC architecture. The basic component of any network communication is data, which is in the form of packets, frames, or bits.

item.title: The Emperor's Proclamations
item.description:
The Emperor's Proclamations

Dynamic VLANs are a fairly common feature used in large corporate enterprise applications such as hospitals, universities, large corporate offices, and similar.Dynamic VLANs are fairly unusual in SMB environments, as WPA2 Enterprise is required as a prerequisite, though using WPA2 Enterprise does not necessarily require use of Dynamic VLANs.

item.title: CWNP
item.description:
CWNP

I literally just came out of the testing centre having taken the CWDP exam. The certification process opened my mind to different techniques and solutions. This knowledge can only broaden your perspective. Great job, CWNP, you have a great thing going on here.

item.title: Airheads Community
item.description:
Airheads Community

This is the third blog post in a series about WLAN capacity planning. Be sure to read the first and second posts. In my previous post, I outlined the major factors affecting network performance, including geographic delay (latency), serialization delay (commonly referred to as bandwidth or speed), and variable contention delay (another form of latency, often forgotten).

item.title: CWNA Study Guide Book Review
item.description:
CWNA Study Guide Book Review

You were tasked with deploying WiFi for the enterprise. To your surprise, it hasn't been working well. People are complaining it's slow and they can't get work done. Getting a WiFi signal is easy but deploying it correctly is a process. You need the CWNA study guide.

item.title: Moo-MIMO - Divergent Dynamics
item.description:
Moo-MIMO - Divergent Dynamics

I readily admit that I could be all wet on this blog, so I have posed the title as a request rather than an assertion. I am going to state my current opinions on various aspects of 802.11ac Wave-2 technology, as it relates to enterprise customers, in the hopes that if I'm off-base, someone smarter than me will help me understand the error(s) of my thinking.
